The safest sign of regime change is when they begin to attack the statues .
The Americans appreciate it as much as any other - hence the carefully staged fall of Saddam Hussein at the Firdos Square in Baghdad in 2003 .

Stephen Miller , one of the key ideologues of the Trump regime , certainly knew what he did when he took a symbolic axe to the status of freedom in a heated dispute with Jim Acosta of CNN on President ’ s proposals to drastically restrict legal immigration .
To remain fair , Miller did not attack the statue itself .
A Horde of boat owners and Liberty imitators would have liked him to have done so .

But he attacked their importance , and especially the importance that was attributed to it when the famous poem of Emma Lazarus was added to its base in 1903 , 17 years after the completion of the monument .
When Miller Acosta summoned : " I do not want to go into a complete story here , but the status of freedom is ... a symbol of American freedom that brightens the world .
The poem you refer to , which was added later and is not part of the original Statute for Freedom ' .
Miller is factually right , but , as he himself put it , it is not really about history .

It is about the contemporary resonance to the upset words of Lazarus , the only ones in which a state invites not only any old immigrants , but the poorest of the poor : ' Your tired , your poor , your afflicted masses who yearn to breathe freely , / the miserable waste of your rich coasts . '
There was never a time when the " miserable waste " on our screens was better to see .
Miller did not engage in literary criticism - he made it clear that these people are not welcome in Trump ’ s US .
This conflict because of the importance of a statue is part of a broader political and cultural debate : indeed , it is a conflict about America ’ s importance .
Lazarus - and their friends who committed themselves to placing their words at grassroots level after they died - knew very well that they did a highly political act .
The sculpture should show the links between French and American Republican by portraying the female embodiment of freedom in a worn classic image .
Lazarus changed this meaning : in her poem , the female figure is no longer abstract - she received a voice .
And she gives himself a very different name : mother of exiles .
The combination of the poem with the image is a brilliant feminist coup and a devastating attack on American nativism .
And , just as Lazarus changed the meaning of the statue , the right wing people wanted to change it long ago .

The great shrewd Rush Limbaugh , a kind of John of the Baptist for the coming of Trump , argued in 2010 that the Statue of Liberty was not inviting anyone , but rather an early neo-conservative , bringing the American flame into the surrounded world : " Lady Liberty is moving forward .
It should bear the torch of freedom from the United States to the rest of the world .
The torch is not intended to illuminate the path to the United States . '
Limbaugh hit something quite unusual here .
The importance of the statue is quite a matter of the position of perception .
The great imaginative act of Lazarus was to see them as seen by the exhausted , miserable , but hopeful people after long and often terrible journeys on the decks of ships .
The real point is to see the world from the perspective of people seeking refuge and an opportunity to improve their lives .
Their statue speaks to them the words of hope and welcome that they must hear .
And that , of course , is not the prospect that Miller and Trump ever want to recognise .
Their torch is not to illuminate the path , but to ignite the hatred that is their only source of power .
